node.contents: What is it you're trying to achieve? There's many ways to enable security within Java the simplest being a security policy. I'd take a look there first as they allow you to provide access control in a robust way - http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.4.2/docs/guide/security/permissions.html

node.contents: Is it possible for a class to impersonate its identity? For example, Class A attempts to access Class B methods. Class B methods uses getClass().getName() to attempt to check Class A to ensure it is who it is. Can impersonation take place ? e.g. Class C impersonates Class A to get pass the getclass().getName() Class B uses for checks?

astNode.text: Is it possible for a class to impersonate its identity? For example, Class A attempts to access Class B methods. Class B methods uses getClass().getName() to attempt to check Class A to ensure it is who it is. Can impersonation take place ? e.g. Class C impersonates Class A to get pass the getclass().getName() Class B uses for checks?

node.contents: If Class B wants to implement getClass().getName() for checks effective on the sample method below, how do I implement it properly in the sample code below ?

astNode.text: If Class B wants to implement getClass().getName() for checks effective on the sample method below, how do I implement it properly in the sample code below ?

elements.contents: public byte[] getStoragePrivateKey(String application) { if (application.getClass().getName().equals("correctClass") { // Allow access to Private Key. } else { // Access denied } }

node.contents: @Tom Hawtin, not without breaking the license agreement. But it is technically possible. I have written articles of the uses of a self compressing String, a Runtime which reports where calls to gc() are made etc. Terracotta changes the java.* class at runtime, Profiler inject code to any class to obtain additional information. However, I don't believe they load multiple copies.

astNode.text: @Tom Hawtin, not without breaking the license agreement. But it is technically possible. I have written articles of the uses of a self compressing String, a Runtime which reports where calls to gc() are made etc. Terracotta changes the java.* class at runtime, Profiler inject code to any class to obtain additional information. However, I don't believe they load multiple copies.

node.contents: @Peter Lawrey You can replace parts of the Java library with `-Xbootclasspath` or similar, but you shouldn't be able to use class loaders to pull it off.

astNode.text: @Peter Lawrey You can replace parts of the Java library with `-Xbootclasspath` or similar, but you shouldn't be able to use class loaders to pull it off.

node.contents: This won't work: In your example application.getClass().getName() will always return "java.lang.String", as you are getting the type of the "application" parameter.

astNode.text: This won't work: In your example application.getClass().getName() will always return "java.lang.String", as you are getting the type of the "application" parameter.

node.contents: Moreover, in Java, the invoked method can not find out the type from where it's being invoked, so perhaps, you should check your design, implementing some other kind of access control.

astNode.text: Moreover, in Java, the invoked method can not find out the type from where it's being invoked, so perhaps, you should check your design, implementing some other kind of access control.
